results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

9:30 a.m.-noon, Ages 12+

This is the last scheduled work event of this year, so if you were planning on coming out to help year, this is the last chance.

In the spring and fall we plant native species, and we are always trying to remove invasive plants, and clear and line trails at the Forest and Wildflower Preserve. (Adult supervision required below age 15.) For October, we are still attaching knotweed at the back of the Preserve and covering it with plastic to kill it. Location: The dog park off Crest Drive. group.name: South Mountain Conservancy Activities Meetup Group

results.description:
Join us for a mid-autumn hike across the Blackhead Range in the Catskills.  

About this hike:

https://share.grownocean.com/adventures/303

We will meet at the trailhead at the end of Big Hollow Road at 9:30 am on October 17.  We will first make our way to the summit of Blackhead Mountain, then to the summit of Black Dome Mountain, the summit of Thomas Cole Mountain, back to the Black Dome Mountain summit and then finally back to the trailhead.  

We will be hiking at a moderate pace but will wait for all hikers in the group at each trail junction.  The hike will be nearly 9 miles total and we will experience an elevation gain/loss of about 2,000 feet.  More details about this hike in the link below:

https://share.grownocean.com/adventures/303


Getting There:

You will need a car to get to the trailhead.  Please let the organizers know if you have a car and are able to pick up others without transportation.  Likewise, please let the organizers know if you require transportation.  We will do our best to accommodate everyone.

Please note that there is no cell phone reception at the trailhead. If you are late, there will be no way to contact the organizers and you may be hiking on your own.  Please do not be late.


What to expect:

The Blackhead Range is a difficult and strenuous hike but the hard stuff is mostly on the upper section of Blackhead Mountain.  The photograph below is of the three mountains that we will be hiking.

On a clear day, there are sweeping views of the Catskills from Blackhead and Black Dome mountains.  Charge your phones and/or bring a camera!  The fall colors will be in full bloom in the lower sections of the mountains and the upper sections will be about a week past peak.  This hike is one of the most scenic in the Catskill Mountains.


End of Hike:

We will meet at the parking lot at the trailhead at the end of the hike.  Afterwards, the group will head to Cave Mountain Brewing Company in Wyndham, NY for some well earned drinks and food:  

http://www.cavemountainbrewing.com


Mandatory Read:

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. 

*We strictly practice and enforce the Leave no Trace ethos.  We expect all hikers to abide.  

https://lnt.org


Questions:

[masked]

results.description:
We usually play one or two ~7 inning games. You can come for one or both. Teams are randomized before each. The lineups are locked at 13.

We play without a permit. We try to be aware of the field's availability but there is always a chance that we'll get kicked off by a permit-holder or that someone else will grab the field before us. (This has happened 2-3 times per year on average and we are usually able to relocate to a backup field 5-10 minutes away.)

Our annual costs:
meetup.com: $144
domain name: $15
clincher balls: $300

A suggested cash contribution of $15/year would be appreciated if you come regularly. (Electronic payment is easier). Or you can bring clincher balls (though we currently have a considerable stock remaining from last year).

results.description:
Terry Fox 5K Run

Working Together To Outrun Cancer


Participation and fundraising are the goals. All proceeds are donated to support cancer research at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

Video of Race: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bcz5TTd0vb4

Registration

Registration area is easy to find.  There will be multiple tents located in the Mall area just West of the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park.  The Naumburg Bandshell is South of the 72nd Street Transverse (and south of the Fountain and the Boathouse).

From the East Side, enter on 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue and stay on the 72nd Street Transverse (past Central Park Drive) until you see the Naumburg Bandshell (South of the Fountain).

From the West Side, enter on 67th Street and Central Park West and keep walking East to the Naumburg Bandshell

Event Location & Directions

Central Park, Naumburg Bandshell - South of the 72nd Street Transverse.

Directions: By subway: East Side: Take the 6 train to the 68th Street stop on Lexington Avenue - then walk West to Central Park at 72nd Street.  West Side: Take the 1 or 9 on the IRT to the 66th Street station. Or use the local train on Central Park West to the 72nd Street station. Walk to the West 67th Street park entrance past Tavern on the Green (under construction) and keep heading East. Link for subway: www.nycsubway.org

Start:

On 72nd Street Transverse runners run West to Central Park Drive then turn South and do two laps of the Lower Loop of Central Park.

Course:

Two laps of the Lower Loop of Central Park


Finish Line:

On the Second lap, runners will be heading North on Central Park Drive East and then turn left (West) onto the 72nd Street Transverse to the Finish Line.  Finish Line will be marked by a large red and white balloon arch.  The Finish Line is on the 72nd Street Transverse just South of the Fountain.

Schedule of Events

Set Up 7:00 am - 8:00 am  -  Registration 8:00 am - 9:30 am

Terry Fox Run begins 9:30 am - Raffle Prizes 10:20 am

No Entry Fee

We encourage everyone to pre-register, however, you can register in Central Park on the morning of the run.  Everyone is Welcome!

Additional Event Information


T-Shirts: All participants will receive a free T-Shirt (while supplies last). 

Pre-Registration: On Friday, October 16, 2015  from 11:00 am to 7:00 pm on the lower level in front of the Cosmopolitan Suite of the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan (57 East 57th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues). Please visit the pre registration desk.

Run Day Registrations and Donations: Run day registrations and donations will be accepted at the Run site on Saturday, October 17, 2015 at the Registration tent.

Raffle Prizes: All participants will be eligible (and free of charge) to win some fabulous raffle prizes donated by various organizations. One catch: You must be present at the drawing to win a prize. The raffle will take place after the run at approximately 10:20 a.m.

Food & Beverages: Coffee, hot chocolate, juices, fruits and pastries will be available before and after the run courtesy of the Four Seasons Hotel.

Baggage Check: Will be available in the Registration Area

Pre-Register Here:  Click Here for more Info and to Register

results.description:
Film Costume / Rendering Realities

Saturday, October 17, 2015
9:30 am to 6:00 pm
New York University

Einstein Auditorium, 34 Stuyvesant Street
New York, NY 10003

This one-day conference at New York University focuses on film costume and history. A collaboration between two departments at NYU – the Cinema Studies program in Tisch School of the Arts and Costume Studies in NYU Steinhardt – Film Costume / Rendering Realities investigates film costume’s role in cinema’s multiple constructions of history and what impact those historical renditions have on culture. Within this overall focus, the program includes a keynote conversation between two innovative scholars on film costume, a range of presentations on international costume, a discussion on urban style among costume designers and filmmakers, and a special panel of curators and auctioneers about their understanding of what display and collection of actual costume means, both personally and publicly.

Bringing together those who work in costume, cinema and scholarship – a first-time opportunity for many – with an emphasis on discussion, research and an interchange of ideas, Film Costume / Rendering Realities examines and celebrates one of cinema’s most crucial arts with an audience of students, industry professionals, academics, and the film-loving public.

More information on the speakers can be found here.

SCHEDULE

9:30
Check-in and coffee

10:00
Welcome and introduction:
Drake Stutesman and Nancy Deihl

10:15
Keynote Conversation – Costume, Ongoing Ideas
Stella Bruzzi with Jane Gaines

11:15
Panel discussion – Designing Urban Realities
Costume designers John Dunn, Dona Granata, Maren Reese

12:00
Morning Q&A

12:30-2:00
Lunch
Catered lunch for all attendees on 6th floor

2:00
Presentations
From the Vamp to the “Vampesque”: Costume and Star Text in 1970s Hindi Film,
Tarini Sdirhana, PhD candidate, NYU Tisch

Dreaming Epic Cinema: Edwin Austin Abbey and D.W. Griffith
Lucy Oakley, Head of Education and Programs, Grey Art Gallery, New York University

2:45
Presentation Q&A

3:15-3:30
Short break

3:30
Panel discussion – Ghosts in the Wardrobe Department
Lucy Carr, Associate Specialist for Entertainment Memorabilia, Bonhams Auctioneers; Jean Druesedow, Director, Kent State University Museum; Nancy Friedland, Film Media Librarian, Columbia University; Barbara Miller, Curator of the Collection and Exhibitions, Museum of the Moving Image; Jill Morena, Assistant Curator of Costumes, Harry Ransom Center

4:30
Panel Q&A and Conference Wrap-up

5:00-6:00
Closing Reception

This event is open to the public, advance registration is required.
General registration is $30.
Free admission for all students. Questions?
For information: [masked]

Conference organized by New York University’s programs in Cinema Studies and Costume Studies

Special thanks for their support and sponsorship to NYU Steinhardt Department of Art and Art Professions; New York University Cinema Studies, Tisch School of the Arts; NYU Steinhardt 125th Anniversary Fund; Swarovski

Information Session

Tuesday, October 27, 2015
6:00pm
New York University
Room 307, 34 Stuyvesant Street

Learn about Costume Studies at NYU at the upcoming information session. The session is for prospective applicants providing them an opportunity to meet program faculty and current students. To RSVP, please email [masked].

Serpents and Eagles: Dress and Textiles of Southeast Asia

Saturday, November 14, 2015
1:00pm-5:00pm
New York University
Einstein Auditorium, 34 Stuyvesant Street
New York, NY 10003

This will be an afternoon devoted to Southeast Asian dress and textiles - with speakers, interviews and a fashion show of traditional Thai dress.

This event is free and open to the public..

venue.name: Stanley Isaacs Senior Center

results.description:
This volunteer opportunity helps a segment of the NYC population that is particularly vulnerable (our home-bound seniors) and is facing a steadily growing problem - hunger. As our city’s elderly grow older, they are more likely to have mobility limitations, while living at or below the poverty level. The elderly of East Harlem are particularly more vulnerable, residing in challenging living conditions alone, and who can no longer shop or cook for themselves.

Citymeals-on-Wheels (www.citymeals.org) raises private funds to ensure no homebound elderly New Yorker will ever go a day without food or human company. Citymeals funds 33 community-based agencies that bring weekend, holiday and emergency meals to homebound elderly New Yorkers - one of the agencies we'll be helping as volunteers.

How are we helping?

On Saturday, October 17th, we'll assist the Stanley Isaacs Senior Center Citymeals-on-Wheels program with delivery of meals to the elderly. Volunteers should wear weather appropriate clothes and comfortable shoes as deliveries are done on foot within walking distance from the meal center.  Although the weather may not always be favorable, the meals MUST be delivered as many, if not all, of the elderly in the program RELY on the meal delivery for the day.

Our Meetup

We'll meet at the Senior Center at 9:30am on Saturday for a short training, then break into small teams of 3 to 4 people to deliver the meals to the elderly. A light breakfast of juice, coffee, pastry and/or bagels will be offered.

If you RSVP, please try to be on time, or arrive no later than 9:30am, which is when we start delivery. The time commitment ends at 12pm and goes by very quickly. 

If you have any questions, running late, need more information on parking and etc., feel free to call/text Daniel at 774.275.3646.

Directions to the Union Settlement Senior Center

The Stanley Isaacs Senior Center is located at 415 East 93rd Street. The closest subway is the #6 train to 96th Street & Lexington Avenue, then walking east to 93rd street & 1st Avenue. The building is offset from the street (toward the FDR Drive), enter through sliding glass doors. The M15 bus line stops nearby, along 1st Avenue (uptown) or 2nd Avenue (downtown).

Thanks and see you there!

results.description:
Let's welcome fall! Enjoy a hike/rock scramble while taking in some magnificent views of the preserve's fall foliage. Highlights: Insane views, cool stroll around Mohonk Mountain House and property, crazy rock labyrinth, claustrophobia-defying climb up a deep crevice, Sky Top Tower

Distance: 8 - 10 miles, loop

Approximate round trip time: 6- 7 hours (Depending on your pace)

Total ascent: 973 ft

Max Elevation: 1,617 ft above sea level

Entrance fee: $12.00 per person. Groups of 30 or more must register for permit prior to date.

Pooch proclivity: No doggies allowed

Descriptions: Up the steep stone stairs to stay on the carriage roads to Mohonk Mountain House. Rock scramble at the Labyrinth and up the lemon squeeze to the top. Lunch and then up the tower house for the 360 view of Mohonk Preserves.

Required Gear:

Hiking boots

change of socks

Sunscreen

Windbreaker

Hat

Climbing gloves (Home Depot and Walmart has cheap gardening gloves with good grip)

2.5 liters of Water

Lunch and snacks

Head lamps

Cash $

And don’t forget your camera :) !

Driving Directions: New Paltz Exit 18 off of the NYS Thruway. 7 miles west (through New Paltz) on Route 299 to the end. Right on Route 44-55. The Preserve Visitor Center will be 1/2 mile on the right.

*** THIS EVENT WILL BE CANCELLED IF IT’S 30 - 50% CHANCE OF RAIN. RESCHEDULE DATE IS SUNDAY ***

Remember it's up to you to take the initiative to find your own rides. Post a comment below if you're a passenger that needs a ride (splits gas/tolls) or a DRIVER that can pick people up. If you don't get a response, you can contact the driver via their profile page or if they have a post stating that their offering a ride. If still that leads to nowhere, rent a car is an option or contacts me VIA TEXT ONLY PLEASE.

Participation in activities is strictly voluntary and group members assume all risks in connection with activities; per Meetup.com's Terms of Service Agreements, organizers and hike/trip leaders are released from any and all forms of liability related to events.

This hike is for you if: You want to see some of the coolest sights in the Hudson Valley and you’re not afraid to crawl under (and around, and through, and over) some rocks to see ‘em.

Text me at[masked] for any questions.

results.description:
This hike is for members who have never been on a hike with this group before. I know some of the hikes fill up quickly, so this is a chance for those who have never been on a hike with this group to go.   You will be taking off the attendee list if you have attended a hike before.  

We did this hike in the spring and it was very popular.   We follow the Croton Aqueduct Trail from Ossining to the Croton Dam.  We then double back and hike through Croton Harmon along the Croton River.   Because of a certain park we pass through please don't bring your dog on this hike.

The hike follows the route of the historic Old Croton Aqueduct from Ossining to Quaker Bridge, continues through parkland in the Village of Croton, and returns via the Croton Harmon Train Station.  Some of the nicest parts of the Aqueduct Trail are on this stretch.  The Croton Dam is spectacular and not to be missed.  

It’s not a long hike, about 7.5 miles and will take 6-7 hours is considered easy to moderate. 

Meet at the Grand Central information booth at 9:30.  We will take the 9:43 to Ossining arriving at 10:28.

Bring plenty of water and a packed lunch.  We will find a nice place to stop along the way. 

Follow the link for more details. 

http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/old-croton-aqueduct-ossining-quaker-bridge
results.name: New Member/First Time Attending Hike - Ossining to Croton-Harmon

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
A weekend workshop with Dr. Kristina Kincaid
Liberate Eros In Every Dimension Of Your Life! 

What can the Erotic teach us about the Divine? In modern Western thought the sexual is often seen as the being the opposite of the spiritual. When we understand and access the rich interplay between the erotic and the sexual, we can tap into a limitless reservoir of spiritual wisdom.

“The sexual models the erotic” as Dr. Marc Gafni says. “but it does not exhaust it.” In this groundbreaking workshop your are invited to accept Eros as your Spiritual teacher- a teacher that will guide you with tenderness and sweetness toward “being a lover” in every aspect of your life.

IN THIS WORKSHOP YOU WILL LEARN:

- to deeply understand the powerful relationship between the erotic and the holy,
- the difference between ordinary and extraordinary sexing,
- to access the difference between Love, Sex and Eros,
- to liberate eros in every dimension of your life,
- to radically submit and accept the sexual as your wisdom teacher,
- to access the full power of sexual fantasy as your tool for liberation and empowerment,
- why hot sex is not secular but sacred,
- to navigate the razor's edge between domination and submission and mutuality,
- the distinction between raunch and ravishing, submission and surrender,
- the 3 levels of consciousness and how they will change your entire sexual experience,
- why most sexual failure is not a crisis of technique but of imagination,
- how to move through the abuse of the sexual to sexual integrity (integration of the sexual)


When: Sat and Sun, Oct 17th - Oct 18th, 2015, 10 AM~5 PM
Where: Institute of Core Energetics,
150 West 28th street, suite 1803, New York

Led by Kristina Kincaid in conjunction with
The Institute of The Integral Evolutionary Tantra
Co-leaders Cynthia Kagoshima, CCEP and Tara Urszula Pietrzykowska

IET is a division of the Center for Integral Wisdom

When you register or attend, please make a point to tell the facilitator that you heard about this event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup.


Admission: $245 before Oct 5th, 2015, $295 after

Tickets:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-erotic-and-the-holy-tantra-of-everyday-living-tickets-17754420951

Bio:
Dr. Kristina Kincaid is the Director of The Institute of Integral Evolutionary Tantra, New York City. Kristina is on faculty at The Institute of Core Energetics and holds an M.A. in Energy Medicine and a Doctorate in Theology from Holos University. She is also a graduate of the Institute of Core Energetics and Barbara Brennan School of Healing. Her journey has taken her into deep explorations and healing around sexuality. She has a healing practice in NYC.
results.name: The Erotic And The Holy: Tantra of Everyday Living

results.description:
First Ever Startups-on-Steroids Build-A-Thon


Saturday, Oct. 17, 10am - 2pm

Become a partner in a growth-hacking-full-stack-marketing-super-agency that gets equity in everything it builds

• THIS is a FREE event BUT you MUST RSVP HERE at eventbrite!!!!!

What I am looking for…

If you are a pioneer who wants to be a full-time partner in the next evolution of startup acceleration this event is for you. You must be ready to become a partner in your own business. We will build the ground floor of a kickass digital marketing and product development agency.  The founding partnership in the agency is four way: 4 X 25%. 

What you must be…

You need to be ready to take a risk. There are no guarantees and the first 4 - 6 months may involve irregular pay. Everything we are doing is an experiment in building the next gen. hyper-efficient company.  No one has done what we are attempting. You will learn about balanced job complexes. You will be challenged by a spectrum of high-end conceptual-strategy work and mundane-grunt work. But, you will be experiencing these in a completely new, fast-paced, participatory, knowledge-sharing environment. You will have more responsibility and more reward.

What you will experience…

If this works you will become part of a self-replicating, team-generating, non-hierarchical network based company. We grow without departments, without middle management, and with a ridiculous competitive advantage. We are superfast, super responsive, super-efficient, and committed to the flat model that keeps us that way.

Who I am...

My name is Atma - I am a behavioral scientist who specializes in startups and entrepreneurship. 

What I have built...

Using a new application of the lean framework I have reinvented the startup accelerator - this means I will create more successful startups than any program out there. 

Why I have built this

The future belongs to the creative, adaptive, meaning-creating, clear-thinkers. The paradigm I am introducing prepares all its participants for this future; a future without zero-sum, soul-stealing workplaces.

My Problem

Because my model relies heavily on testing cycles, lean growth hacking, full stack marketing and lean product development I have hit a bottleneck with my member companies.  I simply do not have the bandwidth to support them with all the steps involved.  

Going to outside agencies is not a solution.  They are too siloed, too expensive, and too far out of my full stack lean framework. 

Your opportunity

Consequently, you have a chance to become a founding partner in a new kind of support agency to match the needs of this evolutionary accelerator.

Therefore I am announcing the first Startups on Steroids Agency Build-a-thon. The goal is to find four partners and build the agency in one night.

This highly unusual and experimental event aims to create a partnership of full stack digital marketing, growth hacking, UX product development, and possibly design and coding experts.  We will select an interdisciplinary team, who together will become superstars capable of using my framework to make startups succeed.  In other words, we will endeavor to build a new kind of agency in one night. 

Why do this in a one night event?

First, we are in a big hurry because we have clients waiting. We have at least  three clients with funding who are ready to start, and several others who are interested, but were unwilling to commit because the agency was not ready. Additionally, the sooner we exist as an agency the sooner I can continue my already successful sales process.

Second, this collaborative event is the future of hiring. This event is representative of how we operate and how we teach others to hire and grow.

Three openings - 4 partners

We will be looking for a total of 3 new partners (not including me - I will be the in charge of sales and strategy and be the managing partner).

These are the suggested roles for the agency, based on both the priority of need and the flow of our full stack lean framework: 

1)  Full stack digital marketer/growth hacker and engagement expert (validation and scale) [wanted]

Manages campaign: Optimisely, webhooks, keyword planning, ad words buys, Facebook ad creation (LinkedIn, too), A/B testing, stochastic data analysis, manage incremental ad budgets...

Manages customer acquisition:  inbound marketing, outbound marketing

SMM, SEO, CRM, pipeline analytics, referral engagements, basically full funnel discovery…

This role spans the discovery stage, which is pre-product/market fit and the scaling stage, which is post-product/market, fit. 

2)  Lean Creative & Design [wanted]

Manages creative: works with outsourced support - supervises: copywriting, explainer video, landing page development; anti-design (aka lean design), color schemes, style guides, usability, and affective interaction. 

As the client grows, this will include coordination of brand strategy, content strategy, blogger relations, and community management.

3) Lean Product development [wanted]

Manages MVPs, rapid prototyping, and single feature releases: supports lean development, works with offshore coders, and supervises surveys and ethnographic interviews, supervises tech issues. 

This role is an important part of the product/market fit discovery process. It will require someone with a good understanding of UX and product development. While the role also requires an experiential understanding of coding and product development, it is unlikely that it will involve much coding.

 4) Sales & Strategy [Atma]

Client acquisition, agency strategy, organizational development, business development.

The future of teams - circles not pyramids

These roles have a great deal of potential fluidity. We, however, will be going beyond fluidity and creating the agency model of the future. In this lean model, everybody gets to do fun work (conceptual-strategizing-thinking-stuff), but we all share in the grunt work (mundane, rote tasks, like execution and boring stuff). This new distribution of tasks into balanced job complexes has a profound impact on the psychology and efficiency of the team. Suddenly the group mind is able to work much more effectively and to streamline much of the grunt work. 

It does mean learning some new skills, often in areas beyond your initial expertise. Even so, this cross-learning, and sharing of grunt work goes a long way to enhancing the group’s capacity and efficiency.  It also provides a way to even out the workflow. This is evolutionary shit.

A night of games ands problem solving

You are invited to an event that shows us how teams with collaborative chemistry self-select. This is the next level of team and organizational development.

Creating the ideal workplace

An agency is not a 10X proposition (meaning something that will scale exponentially). But, an agency with a fee + equity arrangement with its clients will be a self-sustaining entity that pays good salaries, benefits, bonuses, and provides some future security to its founders and employees. While the early founders will get some financial incentive for taking the risk of establishing this agency, in the long run it will become a highly equitable place, where revenues support all the employees proportionately and appropriately. 

In fact, because I specialize in creating highly functional-fun workplaces, this may be one of the coolest places to work.  

How the business will operate

This will be a partnership that will work with the many emerging startups in the Startup Ecology pipeline. Our new super agency will be an arm (or sister?-still working out the metaphors) of our accelerator.  As such, the agency will share in the equity of the accelerator (which of course is taking equity in all the emerging companies).  The agency will get paid for its work but at a discount since they are also accruing equity. Some of the fees will come directly from members in the pre-accelerator, and some will come from our own internal fund used to support those startups that have qualified for support.  

Startup Ecology (the accelerator our agency is a part of) takes 1% equity for every $4000 of services we provide (up to 9%). Because our clients are part of a cradle to exit accelerator program, and because we are growing them and understanding them across all facets of their business development, we are able to be very specific and lean in the support we give them.  

Our clients are many times more likely to succeed than a typical agency’s client.  Our clients are high-level entrepreneurs who are trained in all the best practices of entrepreneurship 3.0. Consequently, they are also far less demanding to work with since they are following our lead and our instructions. This reduces account management and considerably simplifies client-agency relationships. 

The agency is being designed to be its own self-sustaining profit center.  In the beginning wages will be kept low (with no guarantees) and apportioned as disbursements to partners. 

We will actively seek clients for the agency bringing them in both directly and through the pre-accelerator.  Everybody can (and should) participate in the acquisition process, which involves going to meetups in the evening, meeting nice people.  Often there is beer.

Another cool difference in this type of agency is customer client relations. Our clients generally come from our school and our accelerator. Consequently, they are pre-disposed to do what we tell them to do. We are their growth and innovation department, and they will follow our lead. This removes a huge chunk of the worst source of inefficiency for agency. 


The four ways we gain new clients

  1)  Pre-accelerator -

Companies that are not immediately fundable (and without a valuation) will be recommended to select a low cost package for support, including MVP product development and testing cycles.  These packages will be billed as a combination of cash and equity (1% for every $4000).  In some cases we may elect to defer fees. 

  2)  Accelerator -

Companies that are being supported by our internal fund will have their agency fees covered (also in exchange for equity.) They will also have their coworking fees covered.  Living stipends will be negotiated and require submission of personal finances.

  3)  Direct to agency -

While we primarily want clients that have been through our startup training program and are in our accelerators program, we will accept clients directly into the agency at full price. Even so, they will be encouraged to eventually join the accelerator program if that is appropriate and in both their and our interests.

   4) Our school: an important funnel 

A very effective means of attracting startups to our agency is our online school. This school, based on my framework, The Seven Disciplines of Successful Startups, is unlike any training program available.  Built on a new type of LMS platform it provides moderation, peer coaching, and access to mentors.  Additionally, it is available at a low monthly subscription of $29. 

All startups that complete the first 8 lessons are automatically eligible for our pre-accelerator. 

Some additional notes -

Blogger Relations - a separate company, nested inside of the agency, will be created using interns and virtual assistants to create a database of niche bloggers pertinent to our clients. This can become its own profit center and will be able to offer equity to the interns that build it. The structure of the company follows a blogger relations framework that I developed and can be easily replicated.


More info about the framework….

A description of my framework for building startups: 

Full Stack Lean Business Development

 It is now possible (and recommended) to bring the lean framework (originally defined as: making obvious what adds value by reducing everything else, and currently defined as: using the least amount of resources to prove or disprove assumptions) to the entire business development cycle. 

 This full stack of lean business development includes the following 7 Disciplines:

Lean Mindset       -        Assumption detection, bias avoidance, creativity enhancement (exploiting constraints), capacity assessment, precise resource allocation, scientific journaling, cultural onset and early team development (MVT), natural language partner agreements.

Lean Development    -        Rapid prototyping, single feature assessments, MVPs (elevator pitches, explainer videos., landing page, wizard of Oz, concierge, Kickstarter, webinars, etc.…), generative grammar mind mapping, Lean UX , Lean design, lean usability, user stories, backlog, agile development for teams, agile time management for individuals,  Framework assessment: app development (Python, Ruby, Php, Java, Wp, bootstrap),  manufacturing (3D printing, China, manufacturing clubs…).

Lean Testing Cycles  -   Copy writing, landing pages, explainer videos, FB ads, keyword planning, Adwords, LinkedIn & Twitter ads, Google Analytics, webhooks, stochastic analysis, incremental ad budgets, surveys, ethnographic interviews, idea validation, market validation, growth model validation, creating a culture of discovery.

Lean Customer Acquisition  -    Pipeline development, CRM, acquisition through continual A/B testing of the funnel (first points of contact), testing across multiple channels, viral acquisition, paid acquisition, earned acquisition, inbound tactics (content creation, CTA, follow up), outbound tactics (trolling want ads, call rooms, postcards, paid media, etc.…) SMM, remarketing, cultivating engagement, retention tactics, testing revenue streams, repeat/cross/up/sales, referral generation and support.

Lean Marketing & Branding     -     How to contextualize data points, how to apply narrative methodology, SMO, SMM, SEM, SEO, blogger relations, newsletters, content creation, mailing list management, event sponsorships, novel types of engagement, and community development, helping clients with the creating of meaning.

Lean Funding     -     Pitching, the lean business model & canvas, 3 card pitch deck, 10 card pitch deck, demos, financial models, fundable criteria check list, ringing the cash register, A/B testing prices, levels of funding (bootstrap, F&F, accelerators, seed funding, Series A - D…., Reg A+ crowd funding, IPO, M&A, institutional loans…).

Lean Culture      -              Agile management, autonomous- self managed teams, knowledge sharing culture, high-level collaboration, reciprocal benefit incentives, flat management models, lean hiring methodology, stress management, psychological empowerment, and affective commitment.
results.name: Let's talk about how to build an agency that can support the startup community

results.description:
This is the entry level (1 of 6) for the WTBA's Yang Chengfu's Taijiquan Students Grading System. This class will be open for two months, after which it will be closed until all the students have passed that grading level, and will then transform into Grade 2 class. 

The material and requirements for this level are as follow: 

Yang Chengfu's form:

First 3rd, step 1*.

Qigong:

Should be able to hold standing three circles for 10 minutes.

Single push hands:

Should be able to hold a solid P’eng in a power stance, move from the waist with correct weight shifting, and not let excess tension into the body. 

*Step 1
The form should be done at an all slow pace, i.e. no speeding up or slowing down. Stepping should be done with balance, i.e. the heel should be placed with no weight falling onto it. Stances should be correct width and length, should have hands in correct structure, and center line should face the correct direction. Should also maintain a vertical spine.

Movements that require some momentum can of course be done faster, but should still be done smoothly and gracefully.

results.description:
October is prime Dance Walk weather! Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com

results.description:
The Institute for Architectural Research is offering a basic course on analytical drawing in the urban environment.


Analytic drawing workshop offers basic free hand drawing skills for analyzing visual space through profile, proportion, and scale.

Class will be led by experienced architectural sketching instructors: Michael Sciarrillo, AIA; Scott Aker, AIA; Corey August and Chloe Rice. Students will be taught one-on-one through a series of sequential handcrafted drawings. 

The workshop is open to all levels of experience. There is no requirements for sketchbooks or pencil supplies. Please be prepared with your own material. 

If you would like to buy a sketching kit, The Institute for Architectural Research offers one for the workshops. Kits include a sketchbook, pencils, erasers, and sketch and wash. Kits will be hand delivered at the beginning of the workshop. 


Lastly, the cost of workshop is free for members of the public with low income; students in middle; high school; students currently enrolled in a University. Approval of all free admissions is review by the board of directors. 

For inquiries, and fee waiver, please contact: [masked]

Institute for Architectural Research, Inc. 
www.architecturalresearch.org

Join Caroline for a Holy Yoga flow class accessible for seasoned yogis and beginners alike. 

Our focus in this class will be The Small Things. Our culture places so much value on accomplishment and achievement, but God does not. His enthusiasm for you, his pride and delight in you does not increase on your big days and diminish on your ordinary days. The sequence of our yoga practice on Saturday will embody this. In the small poses and the big ones, the transitional moments and the deep breaths, we'll meditate on God's presence and delight in us.

*Please check the TV monitor when you enter to see what room we are in. And please bring your own mat as this studio does not have extras :)

More info at carolinewilliamsyoga.com

Central Park offers a number of tours, both free and for a minimal cost.  We will explore some of these tours.  

On this first tour we will join Central Park Conservancy guides for an introduction to some of the southern Park highlights, including Grand Army Plaza, the Pond, Gapstow Bridge, Wollman Rink, Chess & Checkers House, and the Dairy.

The tour starts at 11 a.m. but I am posting the event to start at 10:45 a.m. so that everyone makes sure they are there before the tour heads out.  There will not be a way to catch up once it begins.

This tour is only 45 minutes.  So afterwards, we can go find a place to grab a bite to eat, for those who are interested.  Just be aware that the tour ends at a different place than it begins.

Details

Meet: Inside the Park at 61st Street and Fifth Avenue. Tour ends at the Dairy (mid-Park at 65th Street). Map of start location

Terrain: Moderate inclines and some stairs

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Inline skate lesson for Beginner to intermediate skaters.
We should have a great day to skate.
Cost of this class is: $25 per individual class, $45 for 2 classes or $60 for package of 3 classes; fees are collected before class begins, however we suggest that you to pay in advance, using Pay Pal option.

Please note that you must have complete set of protection gear and helmet to participate in class.

We meet in the Blades Skate Store, 156 West 72nd St., near Amsterdam Ave. at 11:00AM, if you need to rent skates and all of your gear. The class leaves for the lesson area by 11:15AM.  We will then walk to the practice area so we are geared up ready to skate by 11:30AM. As a reminder – helmets, wrist, knee and elbow guards are required. These can be rented at Blades if needed. Please have your gear by 1:15PM, so we can get started. If possible, rent the gear the day before the class as it is a 24 hour rental. Please check all of your gear before coming to class to see if it fits properly. Make sure the wheels, buckles, straps, snaps, laces and everything else is in good working order.

Please note that if it is raining or the lesson surface is wet, we will NOT have the class.
If you have any other questions, please post them on this page or text/call me at [masked]

results.description:
Do something GREAT this Summer!!


Take Acoustic Guitar Lessons in Central Park
Free Group Lessons Saturdays, May 16th to October 17.


You will learn to read notes, chords and play songs you know and love.  You will have the opportunity to learn:


• Basic info about the guitar
• To read and play chords
• To read and play Rhythm
• Techniques for using the pick
• How play finger style.
• What you learn can be applied to Rock, Blues, Folk, Country,
   Jazz, Classical
• Plenty of new songs


Anyone can attend and you don't need to attend all the sessions.  A new breakthrough approach, allows each session to be complete even for people who have no experience playing the guitar.  Note: You must RSVP by 9pm on Friday the day before the meetup is scheduled. After 9p.m., registration will be closed.

And after the lesson (12:30 - 1:30p.m), hang out and network with  people, or go check out the sights in the Park!!

WHAT TO BRING:

• Bring your own guitar for these lessons
• Bring a portable music stand if you have one
• Also bring a 3-ring binder and a pencil


OPTIONAL DONATION: The lesson is FREE.  However, your voluntary $5 or  $10 donation help to offset the cost of making the free lessons available to you.



IN CASE OF RAIN:
If it rains, or there's a threat of rain (including if there is rain the night before or in the early morning and the ground is left soggy), we will have the meetup at an indoor location; check the meetup group announcements for update if looks like rain...the alternate location we will meet at is:

The Sony Public Atrium (pictured below)
550 Madison Avenue, NY, NY  10022
Enter on 55th Street, and look for the guitars gathered near the Starbucks to the right of the entrance.

Remember: please update your RSVP if your plans change and you are unable to make it.  If something changes the day of the meetup, please let me know by phone or text at[masked]-1031.

results.description:
In this free 3 hour Workshop, Harvestworks engineer Tommy Martinez will give an introduction to interactive programming in our favorite node-based programming language - Max. Max makes it easy and fun for you to create great media driven works of art. Bring your own laptop with Max 7 installed (www.cycling74.com/downloads) and some sounds and digital video footage of your choosing. During the Meetup you will get an overview of a variety of projects made using Max and get a behind the scenes look at how they were programmed. You will also get some hands on experience with the software to make a fun sound responsive VJ app.

An RSVP is absolutely necessary for this event as space is limited.

Tommy is a New York City based artist, musician, and interactive programmer. He works between sound, video, and software development. You can see some of his programming work at www.customarttools.com. His personal work can be seen at www.thomasjohnmartinez.com

This 2-Day comprehensive workshop explores visual storytelling with dynamic camera movement and skillful actor blocking.

Through extensive, daily hands-on exercises, participants will learn to visualize the scene, work with actors, strategize with storyboards, and evoke the essence of the script: DRAMA!

Participants will learn how to visualize, choose optimum camera positions, camera movement, and lens choices in relations with actor blocking.

Through this process, participants will understand how to convey tone, mood, and style, as well as give the film a distinct look that belongs to the director's unique vision.

FEE: $425 Includes Studio and Equipment

results.description:
Seven Factors of Awakening - CONCENTRATION

This week we continue our discussion of the Seven Factors of Awakening and look at the factor of CONCENTRATION.

CONCENTRATION, known by the Pali word Samadhi, is an important theme in Buddhism and is discussed in several foundational teachings including the Eightfold Path.

We know the main quality of CONCENTRATION as a strong and stable mind that is focused on an object or thought. In this context, at its most focused, all of our internal judgments, commentaries and stories about the object or thought are reduced or drop away.

In the Buddhist teachings there are two main ways we can cultivate our skills of CONCENTRATION. First, by dropping all the stories, judgments, commentaries we have about an object or thought, we are able to have direct experiences with a clear mind of "becoming one with the object with no distractions." Letting go of the stories we create around objects or thoughts may seem like a pretty simple instruction, but since we created those stories, we are strongly identified with them and it's like letting a part of our Self go.

Secondly, we can work with overcoming and getting rid of the obstacles or hindrances to awareness - those things that keep us from knowing what's really going on. As the obstacles of clinging, anger, dullness, restlessness and doubt fall away, we are left with "a natural concentration, a natural clarity, stillness and stability."

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds. 

There are Seven Factors of Awakening in Buddhism.


•  Mindfulness 

• Investigation 

• Energy 

• Joy

•Tranquility 

• Concentration 

• Equanimity
results.name: The Seven Factors of Awakening - Concentration

results.description: Sat., Oct. 17. A very leisurely morning stroll of around a mile in Riverside Park and along the Hudson. Riverside Park is widely regarded as Manhattan's most spectacular waterfront park, and one of only eight officially designated scenic landmarks in NYC. Meet at 11am just outside the northernmost entrance of the Broadway and 96th St. subway station (you get there by taking the 2, 3 or 1 train), If it is not too crowded, we'll plan to have lunch at the Boat Basin Cafe on 79th St., overlooking the park and the river. Otherwise, we'll go on for another half mile to Ollie's at Freedom Place. Afterwards, for those who wish, there's a recital of opera arias at the Library of Performing Arts (free). Please email or call me to make sure that the walk is on and/or if you have any questions. Bob Susser, [masked],[masked]-4371.

results.description:
FOR NEW MEMBERS WHO HAVE YET TO ATTEND ONE OF OUR TOURS:  (There will be a Section 2 posted for all other members).  This tour is full of surprises and fascinating history!  We'll start at the Tweed Courthouse (now the NYC Department of Education) and learn about the colorful history of NYC's most famous corrupt politician.   We'll stop by the African Burial Ground, considered one of the most significant discoveries of the past century.  We'll cover the "Gangs of New York" in the former Five Points area, and after a jaunt through the edge of Chinatown (checking out the oldest tenement building in NYC), we'll traverse the virtually unknown Two Bridges Neighborhood.  As we make our way downtown to the South Street Seaport, we'll pass a bar-restaurant that began serving in 1799, and learn about rich history of the seaport and its role as the world's busiest commercial port in the early-mid 1800's.  Stick around for some optional socializing afterwards! 


This walk is a good 3 miles.  

Cheers from your organizer, Hank

[masked]
results.name: For New Members-Tour of The Five Points, Two Bridges Neighborhood & the Seaport!

results.description:
This one is a schlep north for me, but it's worth it. The vistas! Lots to draw here. (It's also home to the Cloisters, which we won't be going in, but you're welcome to visit afterwards.)

We'll meet at the main entrance to the park, which is the 190th st. stop on the A train.

Any problems on the day of the event, I can be reached at [masked]. 


Looking forward to sketching with you!

What makes our Meetups different from other art groups and classes? There's no instruction, but we like to share our work, and chat and be inspired. Share tips and learn from people in a casual environment where all levels of artists are welcome! Don't be shy to ask anyone anything!

• We sketch for a bit, usually 45 minutes or so, and then get back together and share our drawings, and then sketch again, etc. There's usually time for 3 or 4 sketches.

• Please bring your own supplies - anything you like to work with - pens, pencil, watercolor, pastel, small sketchbook or large paper, iPad, whatever suits you.

• We hand out nametags so everyone can meet one another!

• We take photos to share on the site later. Bring your camera!

• Please take care to make sure we do not leave any trash behind. Please also leave any dogs at home; they tend to knock over the artwork. Thanks. 

• This Meetup is FREE and everyone at all skill levels is welcome!

In case of rain, I will let people know early in the morning if it is canceled, and then reschedule for another day.

How does the Wait List work? If the event is full, rsvp to be added to the Wait List. If someone from the regular list cancels, the first person on the Wait List is automatically bumped up to regular attendee.

Please note that if you add a comment below it will spam everyone with an email, so please use your judgement.
results.name: Draw Fort Tryon Park!

group.name: Central Park Sketching & Art Meetup Group

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
This is the annual battle of the pickups, a mini tournament for those who no longer go to tourneys and is more for bragging rights on who has the "best" pickup.


Teams scheduled to play are: 

East Brunswick, Princeton, Brooklyn, Huntington and 2 Maplewood teams. 

When: Saturday October 17th @ 11:00 - 5:15

Where: Maplecrest Park  

https://goo.gl/maps/HoE5MdFV9tH2


237 Oakland Road, Maplewood. NJ 07040 

Format: 5 game round robin with bye.   


Mixed format, 6-1, 5-2, depending on women participation (which is highly encouraged by all teams).

Who can come?

While this is open to everyone, we ask that you have previously attended either a Tuesday or Sunday pickup. 

To set expectations, this tournament is not for first timers. I suggest you attend one of the Tuesday/Sunday pickups if you are a beginner or new to the game.  

Fees: There is a $75 tournament fee per team. We are asking $5 per person. Overage goes to support the annual meetup site fees.

What To Bring
* Shirts - Light: White, Dark: Red and/or Black
* Cleats - you will need them!
* Water/Snacks (there will be some provisions, but don't count on it. It will be a long day of ultimate).
* A good attitude and good spirit. 

Rules - 11th edition

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
For $3, the Impact Network can educate a student in Zambia for a month.  With that in mind, I'm going to ask for everyone who comes to chip in $3.  What do you get for your money?  Me, my sparkling smile and a giant suitcase full of games to play with for hours.  And with any luck, they'll be spinning vinyl records.  So come, have a beer, meet good people, listen to some funky music and play great games for a good good cause.  I challenge you to find a better deal for three bucks! 

Four people build a miniature city in Medina

What are we going to play? In the lead to Halloween I'll bring some thematic games like "Fearsome Floors" about escaping from a monster.  But I'll bring many of the usual games like Medina,  Nuns on the Run, Avalon, Steam Park, Coup... Honestly, I don't blame you if you haven't heard of most of these games but don't let that stop you!  We'll play relatively simple modern board games that have a 5-10 minute rules explanation and play less than an hour.  They include social negotiation games like Lifeboat and The Resistance or bluffing like Sheriff of Nottingham and Love Letter. I also like games that pack a good punch in a relatively short time frame like King of Tokyo and Fearsome Floors.

What, no Monopoly or Pictionary? Strategy board and card games have changed, grown and evolved so much over the past decade that they have become wonderful art forms in their own right.  They tell stories and provide new situations for engaging each other in ways that party games or old classics can't.  These modern games wouldn't exist if games like Clue and Taboo hadn't paved the way.  But give the next-gen games a shot and you'll see why I'm so much more excited about new games! 

If you're really curious about what I might bring, probe the nerdy depths of my collection and visit my Board Game Geek page.  The bar does have a nice copy of Catan on hand as well.

Build your own amusement park in Steam Park

I'm barely getting out of bed when this is starting! I know that noon on a Saturday is a bit early for people--I get it, believe me--but as long as you show up by 4 (or even 5) you should be able to get some gaming in. 

Skylark is a great bar in Park Slope in its own right.  But they are so board game friendly I just had to move our little meetup there.  They have some good bar food but are also open to bringing food as long as we clean up.

Negotiate for the best stock price with up to 11 people in Panic on Wall Street

My phone number is listed near the top of this posting if you have any questions day-of.  And with that we'll see you on there or else...

Point guns at each other in Ca$h 'n Gun$

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Ensemble class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome!

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."

results.description:
Please note location change for this book discussion.
In 1948 Andrew Wyeth produced what would become one of the most iconic paintings in American art: a desolate landscape featuring a woman lying in a field, that he called "Christina's World." The woman in the painting, Christina Olson, lived in Cushing, Maine, where Wyeth and his wife kept a summer house. She suffered from polio, and was paralyzed from the waist down; Wyeth was moved to portray her when he saw her one day crawling through the field towards her house. "Christina's World" was to become one of the most well-loved and most scorned works of the twentieth century, igniting heated arguments about parochialism, sentimentality, kitsch and elitism that have continued to dog the art world and Wyeth's own reputation, even after the artist's death in 2009. An essay by MoMA curator Laura Hoptman revisits the genesis of the painting, discussing Wyeth's curious focus, over the course of his career, on a deliberately delimited range of subjects and exploring the mystery that continues to surround the enigmatic painting.
Purchasing drinks and/or food at the pub to patronize the establishment and thank them for the use of their space is encouraged and appreciated.
results.name: Andrew Wyeth: Christina's World by Laura Hoptman

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.


Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: C&B sets aside space for us from 12:30pm to 2:30pm so those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer if they wish.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at C&B, you will have to take a lesson from the range staff. If you are an experienced archer, you must at least stay for the safety portion (no exceptions, range rules). Lessons start at half past the hour so if you miss the 12:30pm, you may have to sit around and wait for the 1:30pm. Please be on time.

Public Transportation: LIRR to Hicksville and then a taxi from the station to C&B (make sure to tell them 11 Commercial St in Hicksville). The train from Penn gets into Hicksville at 11:55 am. The cab rate as of 1/1/14 is $6.50 +$2 for each additional person. Those of you taking the train may wish to post a message to the group to share a cab.

Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rates:

$7.00 for the first hour, $5 each additional hour OR $15 to shoot all day
$1.00 for a target
$11 per hour for a rental bow and arrows
$5.00 for a lesson (includes first hour)

Visit the C&B website for the most up-to-date information.

See you on the shooting line!

results.description:
HELLOOOOO BROOKLYN! Our last Amazing Scavenger Hunt Meetup in BK was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team (2-4 members) or as an individual and we will partner you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

What to expect: 


• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*GET TICKETS AT THIS LINK ($30) - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 


What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for a day of walking.  Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers.


What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest.  You can download that before you come.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure hunt. 

What if it rains? This scavenger hunt is INDOORS.

How many people will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup event and we have over 20 groups co-organizing it. We expect up to 40 members to attend.

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/
results.name: The Amazing Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt (includes admission to Museum) PREPAY ONLY
